review.title: GP-Localize: Persistent Mobile Robot Localization Using Online Sparse Gaussian Process Observation Model
review.abstract: Central to robot exploration and mapping is the task of persistent localization in environmental fields characterized by spatially correlated measurements. This paper presents a Gaussian process localization (GP-Localize) algorithm that, in contrast to existing works, can exploit the spatially correlated field measurements taken during a robot's exploration (instead of relying on prior training data) for efficiently and scalably learning the GP observation model online through our proposed novel online sparse GP. As a result, GP-Localize is capable of achieving constant time and memory (i.e., independent of the size of the data) per filtering step, which demonstrates the practical feasibility of using GPs for persistent robot localization and autonomy. Empirical evaluation via simulated experiments with real-world datasets and a real robot experiment shows that GP-Localize outperforms existing GP localization algorithms.

4 Experiments and Discussion
sections.text: This section evaluates the localization performance, time efficiency, and scalability of our GP Localize algorithms, which were empirically determined through simulation experiments using three real-world datasets: (a) Wireless Signal Strength (WSS) (Signalto Noise Ratio) data (Chen and Guestrin 2007) from 6 WiFi Access Points (APs) and measurements at over 200 locations on the fifth floor of Wean Hall at Carnegie Mellon University (Figure 1, Section 4.1), (b) Indoor Environmental Quality (IEQ) (i.e., Temperature (F) and Light (Lux))) data (Bodik et al. 2004), measured from 54 sensors used at Intel Berkeley University. (Figure 3, Section 4.2), (c) Urban Traffic Speeds (UTS) (km / h), data (Chen et al. 2012; 2013), measured on 775 segments of highways, including highways, etc.).

sections.heading: 4.1 Wireless Signal Strength (WSS) Fields
sections.text: Table 1 shows the localization errors (not units specified in the WSS data) of GP-localize, SoD-Truncate and SoD-Even averaged over all 421 time steps and 5 simulation runs. It can be observed that GP-Localize outperforms the other two methods in each individual field and in several fields (i.e. all 6): The observation model (i.e., represented by our sparse online GP) of GP-Localize can use the assimilated summary and recent observations to better predict the fields in explored and unexplored areas respectively. In contrast, SoD-Truncate performs poorly in explored areas because its prediction ability is limited by the use of recent observations. SoDEven's limited observations can only cover the entire area sparsely, resulting in an inaccurate observation model.It can also be observed from Table 1 that GP-Localize does not detect its largest (smallest) localization error in a highly explored (3) field with a robot.

sections.heading: 4.2 Indoor Environmental Quality (IEQ) Fields
sections.text: Table 2 shows the localization errors (m) of the methods tested, averaged over all 336 time steps and 5 simulation runs. Similar to the observations for WSS fields (Section 4.1), GPLocalize outperforms the other two methods in each individual field and in multiple fields, as explained in the previous section. It can also be observed that GP-Localize achieves a smaller error in the light field than in the temperature field, because the measurements of the light field vary slightly more than those of the temperature field, as shown in Figure 3. Figure 2b shows the error of GP-Localize at each time step in each individual field and in multiple fields on average over 5 runs. It can be observed again that the error in multiple fields is not always the smallest at each time step, but often the lowest of all individual fields and not as high as in the individual temperature field. Our GP-Localize algorithm, which uses multiple fields, is therefore more robust in this experiment.

sections.heading: 4.3 Urban Traffic Speeds (UTS) Field
sections.text: In the UTS field, the localization error is defined as the geodesic (i.e. shortest distance) distance between the estimated and the actual inhabited road segments with regard to the topology of the road network (Fig. 4). GP-Localize, SoD-Truncate and SoD-Even have localization errors of 2.8, 7.3 and 6.2 road segments on average over all 370 time steps and 3 simulation runs.

sections.heading: 4.4 Real Pioneer 3-DX Mobile Robot Experiment
sections.text: The Monte Carlo Adaptive Localization Package (AMCL) in the Robot Operating System (ROS) is run on a Pioneer 3 DX mobile robot equipped with a SICK LMS200 laser rangefinder to determine its trajectory (Fig. 5a) and the 561 locations where relative light measurements are performed (Fig. 5b); these locations are assumed to be the ground truth. GP-Localize, SoDTruncate, SoD-Even and SoD-Even each achieve locational errors of 2.1 m, 5.5 m and 4.6 m on average over all 561 time steps and 3 runs. Fig. 4b shows the time GP-Localize, SoDTruncate, SoD-Even, full GP and offline PITC cause at each time step using 100 particles on average over 5 runs.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: This paper describes the GP-Localize persistent robot localization algorithm, whose observation model is represented by our novel GP online selection, which achieves constant time and memory (i.e., regardless of the size of the data) per filter step. We theoretically analyze the equivalence of our GP online selection to the online learning variant of the offline PITC. We demonstrate empirically that GPLocalize exceeds the existing GP localization algorithms in terms of localization performance and scalability and achieves robustness by exploiting multiple fields. In addition to using our GP online selection variant for persistent robot localization, we note that it can indeed be applied to a variety of applications and are particularly desirable (i.e. due to runtime and memory that are independent of the size of the data) for data flow tasks over time or in real-time low visual requirements (i.e., we do not include robotic acquisition, 2002ampling learning, and 2ampling learning).
